animalOfTheDay.name: snowy owl
facts: Unlike most owls, they are diurnal and hunt both day and night in the Arctic tundra.
Snowy owls are one of the largest owl species, with a wingspan of up to 5 feet.
Snowy owls can detect prey moving beneath the snow using their exceptional hearing.
Their feathers are nearly entirely white, providing perfect camouflage in snowy environments.

calendar.name: seahorse
facts: They have prehensile tails to grip seagrass and corals, avoiding strong currents.
They are poor swimmers, relying on camouflage and slow movements to avoid predators.
Seahorses are the only fish where males become pregnant and give birth.
Seahorses lack stomachs and must eat constantly to survive.

calendar.name: serval
facts: Servals have the longest legs relative to body size of any cat.
They can leap 10 feet straight up to catch birds in flight.
Servals have excellent hearing and can detect rodents underground.
They are solitary hunters and mark their territory with urine and scent glands.

calendar.name: siberian husky
facts: Siberian huskies were originally bred as sled dogs.
They are known for their striking blue or multi-colored eyes and thick double coat.
They are energetic and require a lot of exercise.
Siberian huskies are a medium-sized working dog breed.

calendar.name: skunk
facts: Before spraying, skunks usually give a warning by stomping their feet or raising their tail.
Skunks are nocturnal and have poor eyesight but an excellent sense of smell and hearing.
They are immune to snake venom and will sometimes eat venomous snakes.
Skunks are known for their ability to spray a foul-smelling liquid as a defense mechanism, which can reach up to 10 feet.

calendar.name: snail
facts: Snails can sleep for up to three years if the weather isn't favorable.
They have thousands of tiny teeth on their tongue-like radula, which they use to scrape food.
Snails are hermaphrodites, meaning each individual has both male and female reproductive organs.
The largest land snail, the African giant snail, can grow up to 15 inches long.

calendar.name: snow leopard
facts: Snow leopards are known as 'ghosts of the mountains' due to their elusive nature.
They have thick fur and wide, fur-covered feet that act as natural snowshoes.
Snow leopards can leap up to 50 feet in a single bound.
They are unable to roar but communicate with chuffing sounds and growls.

calendar.name: snowy owl
facts: Their feathers are nearly entirely white, providing perfect camouflage in snowy environments.
Snowy owls are one of the largest owl species, with a wingspan of up to 5 feet.
Unlike most owls, they are diurnal and hunt both day and night in the Arctic tundra.
Snowy owls can detect prey moving beneath the snow using their exceptional hearing.

randomAnimals.name: penguin
facts: Penguins propose to mates with pebbles, offering them as gifts to build nests.
Emperor penguins are the tallest, standing up to 4 feet, while little blue penguins are the smallest.
They can drink seawater, thanks to special glands that filter out salt.
Penguins are flightless birds adapted for swimming, with flippers instead of wings.

randomAnimals.name: wild yak
facts: Wild yaks are large cattle from Asia, inhabiting the high, cold plateaus of Tibet and the Himalayas.
They have long, thick fur that helps them survive in extreme temperatures.
Their droppings are often used as fuel by local communities.
They are herd animals, living in groups, and their roar is often heard in the mountains.

randomAnimals.name: snow leopard

They are unable to roar but communicate with chuffing sounds and growls.
They have thick fur and wide, fur-covered feet that act as natural snowshoes.
Snow leopards are known as 'ghosts of the mountains' due to their elusive nature.
